story:
Once upon a time, in a land far, far away, there was a beautiful and prosperous city called Shahr-e-Jahan. In this city, there lived a kind and gentle father named Ali, who had a curious and adventurous young daughter named Zara.

Zara loved to explore the world around her, and she would often ask her father questions about the stars, the trees, and the animals that lived in the nearby forest. Ali was always happy to answer his daughter's questions and to share his knowledge with her.

One night, as Zara was getting ready for bed, she looked up at the sky and asked her father, "Baba, what are stars made of?"

Ali smiled and took a seat next to his daughter. "Stars are made of hot, glowing gas, my dear," he explained. "They are like giant fireflies, twinkling in the night sky."

Zara's eyes sparkled with excitement. "Can we visit a star, Baba?" she asked.

Ali chuckled. "I'm afraid that's not possible, my dear. Even if we could reach a star, we would burn up in its heat."

Zara looked disappointed, but Ali had an idea. "However," he said, "there is a way we can visit a star. Every year, during the festival of Yalda, we gather with our friends and family to celebrate the longest night of the year. During the festival, we stay up late and tell stories by the light of a special fire, which represents the light of the stars. If you close your eyes and make a wish on the fire, it's like visiting a star."

Zara's face lit up with excitement. "Really, Baba? Can we do that tonight?"

Ali nodded. "Of course, my dear. I will gather the materials for the fire, and you can gather your favorite blanket and a special wish to make on the fire."

Zara jumped up and down with excitement. She quickly gathered her blanket and ran to her father, who was preparing the fire. Together, they watched as the flames danced and flickered, and Zara made her wish on the fire.

As she watched the flames, Zara felt a sense of wonder and magic. She knew that, even though she couldn't visit a star in the night sky, she could still experience its beauty and light through the fire and her own imagination.

From that night on, Zara always looked forward to the festival of Yalda and the special connection it brought her to the stars. And every night, before she went to bed, she would look up at the night sky and remember the magic of that one special star that she had visited through the light of the fire.

And so, my dear child, as you drift off to sleep tonight, remember the magic of the stars and the wonder of the world around you. And may your dreams take you on many exciting adventures. Goodnight, my dear. Sweet dreams.
